title-group.article-title: Utility Outcome Assessment of the Aging Neck following Massive Weight Loss

article-meta.aff: 1Division of Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery, Montreal General Hospital, McGill University, Montreal, Canada
2Division of Otolaryngology, Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center, Harvard Medical School, Boston, Massachusetts, USA
3Division of Plastic Surgery, Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center, Harvard Medical School, Boston, Massachusetts, USA

author-notes.corresp: Samuel J. Lin, MD, Divisions of Otolaryngology and Plastic Surgery, Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center, Harvard Medical School, 110 Francis St, Suite 5A, Boston, MA 02215, USA Email: sjlin@bidmc.harvard.edu

permissions.copyright-statement: © American Academy of Otolaryngology—Head and Neck Surgery Foundation 2012
permissions.copyright-holder: Official journal of the American Academy of Otolaryngology–Head and Neck Surgery Foundation

sec.title: Objective
sec.p: The authors set out to quantify the health state utility assessment of living with the physical appearance of the aging neck following massive weight loss. Described utility scores may help to establish the health burden of the aging neck in the growing bariatric patient population.

sec.title: Study Design
sec.p: Prospective cohort observational study.

sec.title: Setting
sec.p: Tertiary referral medical center.

sec.title: Subjects and Methods
sec.p: Three validated tools were used to determine utility scores for living with an aging neck: visual analog scale (VAS), time trade-off (TTO), and standard gamble (SG). A 5-point Likert scale was used to evaluate the subjects’ ease of understanding. A prospective sample of volunteers from the general population and medical students was used for this assessment.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: In total, 118 prospective volunteers were included in the survey. All measures (VAS, TTO, SG); (0.89 ± 0.07, 0.94 ± 0.08, and 0.95 ± 0.10, respectively) varied (P < .0001) from the corresponding ones for monocular blindness (0.62 ± 0.18, 0.87 ± 0.15, and 0.85 ± 0.20, respectively) and binocular blindness (0.32 ± 0.18, 0.66 ± 0.25, and 0.64 ± 0.28, respectively).

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The authors objectified the health state of living with an aging neck in the massive weight loss patient with utility scores (TTO, 0.94) comparable with those living with obstructive sleep apnea. This sample population, if faced with an aging neck following massive weight loss, would undertake a neck rejuvenation procedure with a theoretical 5% chance of mortality and would be willing to trade 2.1 years of remaining life-years to attain this procedure.

body.p: The natural process of aging in the head and neck is a combination of changes in skin texture and decreased facial volume manifested by, among other factors, the loss of tissue elasticity, redistribution of fat, bone resorption, and the effect of gravity.1 Aesthetic enhancement of the aging neck is one of the most challenging components of surgical facial restoration.2 To achieve optimal results in the face and neck, surgical treatment is based on a variety of factors such as the condition of the platysma muscle, redundancy of skin, skin tone, presence of excess submental fat, projection of the anterior mandible, and position of the hyoid bone.3 Indeed, successful neck rejuvenation in the massive weight loss patient may pose additional challenges simply because of the amount of excess skin and subcutaneous tissue. There are various approaches used either individually or combined in an attempt to achieve a desired result. These techniques range from laser resurfacing to modified deep-plane rhytidectomy with a lateral approach, composite rhytidectomy, vest-over-pants platysmaplasty, corset platysmaplasty, submental suction-assisted lipectomy, multiple suture techniques for neck contouring, and chin augmentation, as well as other techniques.2-8

Utility scores have been used to quantify the risk/benefit ratio of a given intervention or nonintervention for a range of conditions, including end-stage renal disease on hemodialysis and after renal transplant,9 human immunodeficiency virus stage II,10 diabetes mellitus type I,11 erectile dysfunction,12 severe breast hypertrophy,13 and obstructive sleep apnea syndrome.14 The use of utility scores may help to establish the health burden of such procedures on patients, providing information on surgical decision making.15 This design permits a comparable quantitative value for health economic decision analysis on behalf of individual health states when assessing health resources for research and treatment.15-17

Utility scores (range, 0 = death to 1 = perfect health) are standardized tools used to illustrate diseases or health states. This design permits a comparable quantitative value for health economic decision analysis on behalf of individual health states when deciding on how to assign health resources for research and treatment.15 There are numerous published validated tools for determining utilities.13,16-18 More than one tool is used to reduce the weaknesses of any other specific tool. Based on previous studies, the visual analog scale (VAS),19 standard gamble (SG),20 and time trade-off (TTO) may be used concurrently to determine the utility of an intervention.21 Utilities can be measured based on the case presentation of the health state in a sample of the general population.13,18

Determining utility outcome scores related to the aging face and neck following massive weight loss may be performed expediently when studying facial appearance. The use of an Internet-based methodology has been used as a means of recruiting a large population-based sample without the need for expert interviewers, which reduces study expenses considerably.13 Our main objective was to compare the health state utility assessment of individuals living with neck laxity in the massive weight loss population who could benefit from rejuvenation surgery using 3 tools (VAS, SG, and TTO) in the general population and medical students and to determine whether utility scores varied with age, education, and race.

sec.title: Materials and Methods
sec.p: The Research Ethics Board at McGill University and the McGill University Health Center approved this study in agreement with the Declaration of Helsinki ethical guidelines for human subjects. All those participating in the study were asked to sign an electronic consent form with the exception of those whose photo appeared in the survey and article; these participants were asked to sign a written consent form to enable the use of their photo for presentations, publications, and research purposes.

Prospective participants from the general population were recruited to a website through online classified ads websites www.kijiji.com and www.craigslist.org. Medical students at McGill University were sent e-mails. All those taking part in the study were then asked to complete health state questionnaires, anonymous demographic questionnaires, and utility assessments. A standard profile image was shown to all participants for visual rating (Figure 1). Three different measures were used: time trade-off, visual analog scale, and standard gamble.

caption.p: Study participants were asked to view a standard profile image (shown) of an individual who would benefit from neck rejuvenation following massive weight loss.

sec.p: The time trade-off assessment asks volunteers to opt for either “trading off” a certain number of years to live in perfect health or to live a set number of years in a described health state. The number of years “traded off” was then varied using a bisecting search routine until the indifference point was found: Utility =(number of years specified in the described health state – number of years traded off at the indifference point) ÷ number of years specified in the described health state.

In the visual analog scale, the subjects were asked to “visualize” themselves as the health state described and to score a value on a slide bar scale from 0 (death) to 100 (perfect health). A utility score was then determined: utility health state = score ÷ 100.

For the standard gamble test, subjects were given 2 choices and asked to pick one: to take a chance (ie, gamble with some probability of success [perfect health] and some probability of failure [death]) or to stay in a given health state. Success and failure were then varied as percentages until the subject was indifferent about whether to remain in the given health state or to take a gamble. The utility score was calculated as follows: utility health state = (1.00 – risk of death at the point of indifference) ÷ 100.9,17

Inclusion criteria to assess the comprehension of the volunteers in the study included the appropriate evaluation of double-eye blindness with a lower utility score (a health state closer to death than perfect life) than single-eye blindness (Figure 2). In other words, those participants who rated double-eye blindness with a higher quality of life than single-eye blindness were excluded. Volunteers who failed to understand the survey were excluded. A valid e-mail address was required to prevent multiple entries.

caption.p: Study design demonstrating inclusion criteria. Those participants who rated double-eye blindness as a higher quality of life than single-eye blindness were excluded.

sec.p: Finally, subjects were asked to rate their own health state using time trade-off and EuroQol.22 A demographics questionnaire was included, and a 5-point Likert scale was used to evaluate the subjects’ ease of understanding of our survey.

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: Analysis was done using statistical software, SPSS for Windows, version 11.0.1 (SPSS, Inc, an IBM Company, Chicago, Illinois). Using the paired t test and independent t test, mean utility scores were compared. Various independent predictors were applied (age, race, and education) for each of the utility scores for the aging neck, and a linear regression was done. To compare categorical variables, the Fisher exact test and χ2 test were performed. Values of P < .05 were considered statistically significant.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Over a 6-month enrollment period, 118 volunteers were included in our survey. Our subjects’ self-utility scores were assessed using TTO and EuroQol in an attempt to address the subjects’ health histories and experiences. A 5-point Likert scale was also used to evaluate the subjects’ ease of understanding of our survey.11-15,22,23 A health state description of post–neck rejuvenation with an accompanying photograph was produced based on both the practiced judgment of physicians and the clinical experiences of patients with related conditions.11-15,22,23 Sixteen individuals were excluded because they rated monocular blindness with a lower utility score than binocular blindness most likely because of their misunderstanding of the survey or “invalid” preference.24,25

Of the 118 unique responses (86.4%), 4 had incomplete entries, and 102 were used for utility assessment. The participants removed from the study did not vary from the study subjects with respect to age (31.1 ± 11.8 years vs 24.86 ± 7.7 years; P = .071) or sex (M/F; 5 [41.7%]/7 [58.3%] vs 38 [37.2%]/64 [62.7%]; P = .815). The mean ± SD age of our subjects was 24.86 ± 7.7 years. The predominant race of volunteers was white (56.2% vs 62.7%; P = .691). Table 1 details study participants’ demographics.

fn.p: Values presented as No. (%) unless otherwise indicated.

sec.p: All measures (VAS, TTO, SG); (0.89 ± 0.07, 0.94 ± 0.08, and 0.95 ± 0.10, respectively) varied from the corresponding ones for monocular blindness (0.62 ± 0.18, 0.87 ± 0.15, and 0.85 ± 0.20, respectively) and binocular blindness (0.32 ± 0.18, 0.66 ± 0.25, and 0.64 ± 0.28, respectively; Table 2) (P < .0001). In this study, the TTO utility scores for the aging neck of 0.94 ± 0.09 and SG utility scores of 0.95 ± 0.10 correspond to a willingness to trade 2.1 years of life ([1 – TTO] × 35 years) and to go through a procedure with a theoretical 5% chance of mortality ([1 – SG]%) to attain perfect health, respectively.

caption.p: Utility Scores of Monocular vs Binocular vs Aging Neck

fn.p: Abbreviations: SG, standard gamble; TTO, time trade-off; VAS, visual analog scale.

sec.p: Utility scores from the VAS did not differ between medical students and the general public (0.90 ± 0.07 vs 0.89 ± 0.07; P = .965). Utility scores were significantly higher in medical students for time trade-off (0.97 ± 0.01) and standard gamble (0.98 ± 0.03) as compared with the general public (TTO, 0.94 ± 0.09 and SG, 0.94 ± 0.12; P = .016 and .017, respectively) (Table 3). Utility scores for whites vs nonwhites were not different (Table 4). The utility scores for female participants were not significantly different from those for male participants (Table 5).

caption.p: Mean Utility Scores of Medical Students and General Population

fn.p: Abbreviations: SG, standard gamble; TTO, time trade-off; VAS, visual analog scale.

caption.p: Mean Utility Scores of Whites and Nonwhites

fn.p: Abbreviations: SG, standard gamble; TTO, time trade-off; VAS, visual analog scale.

caption.p: Mean Utility Scores of Males vs Females

fn.p: Abbreviations: SG, standard gamble; TTO, time trade-off; VAS, visual analog scale.

sec.p: Linear regression analyses revealed that age was inversely proportional to the TTO and SG utility scores (P < .05). For every year increase in the age of the volunteers, there was a decrease of 0.002 in the TTO score. In other words, older volunteers were more willing to sacrifice years of their life for a procedure that may reverse stigma of the aging neck following massive weight loss. Similarly, there was a decrease of 0.004 in the SG utility score for every increase in year of the volunteers. This finding stated that older volunteers were willing to gamble with a higher percentage of chance of mortality for a procedure for neck rejuvenation. Race, level of education, and income were not significant predictors of any of our investigated utility scores.

The participants rated their own quality of life higher than the case of the aging neck patients (TTO, 0.97 vs 0.84; P = .068). The Likert scale clearly illustrates that the most difficult portion of the questionnaire was attempting to depict themselves as the person described in the case examples. Four subjects did not complete the scale.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The process of facial aging is inevitable, and the rate of change differs from one person to the next; the subjective cumulative effect of facial aging varies individually.26 The demand for neck rejuvenation surgery has increased recently from all levels of the socioeconomic spectrum and from different age groups.27 In particular, there is a growing bariatric patient population following massive weight loss interested in head and neck rejuvenation. An individualized surgical plan is performed to improve the aging neck and attempt to regain a more youthful appearance.26,27 However, the perioperative risks associated with such procedures are a significant concern. Also, there is no consensus available as to whether these types of procedures are purely cosmetic or serve a functional purpose. Moreover, there is a lack of objective measures in the available literature of the quality of life of living with the stigma of having received neck rejuvenation surgery regardless of its benefit.

A measure of the quality of life of patients with the appearance of an aging neck following massive weight loss was established in a general population and among medical students. The method of utility outcomes assessment of healthy volunteers as opposed to patients with the disease state has been validated by several studies and reviews.15,18,28,29 The method used in this study has been recommended as an accurate and cost-effective alternative for measuring quality of life.18 In addition, the Panel on Cost-Effectiveness in Health and Medicine recommended that utility assessment should be performed on the latter group,30 and the current authors followed these recommendations. Health utility outcome studies have been performed on healthy volunteers to standardize values of SG, TTO, and VAS across all disciplines; in other words, having a general population determining utility outcomes provides uniformly applicable scores more than having patients with various medical conditions answering the same value questions as each individual will have a different disease course.

We have shown with subgroup analysis that our participants understood the study and rated utility scores of the aging neck similar despite education level and medical knowledge.15 The prospective subjects belonging to the general population serve this study’s purpose to compare this health state with other health states to provide objective data.

Our prospective subjects were provided the lateral view of the neck. Representative photographs of patients with an aging neck following massive weight loss surgery were carefully chosen based on a health state description constructed with expert opinion and the clinical experiences of patients with these similar conditions treated at a tertiary medical center. A single image of the neck was used to help minimize patient confusion regarding the disease state itself. The lateral view presents the most concerning aspect and most visible aspect of the condition. Understanding the causes of neck laxity requires an understanding of the neck anatomy and is essential for providing the best treatment approach and avoiding potential complications.31,32 As one ages, fibers of the platysma become disjointed laterally, which leads to banding, an overly obtuse cervicomental angle, and neck laxity best seen from the lateral view.33 For these reasons, the lateral view was conveyed to the subjects. There are degrees of neck laxity (mild, moderate, severe); for study purposes, we elected to show a single lateral image to prospective volunteers exhibiting moderate to severe laxity to be as clear as possible regarding the physical condition of study.

Single- and double-eye blindness scenarios were used to assess the comprehension of the participants to the study. Only participants who correctly rated double-eye blindness with a lower utility score (ie, higher morbidity) than single-eye blindness were included in the study.15,23 Sixteen participants out of a total of 118 were excluded because they did not meet our inclusion criteria. In a similar study by Cugno et al,34 the authors concluded that their results could help in decision analysis for surgeons.

There was no significant difference in the VAS utility score assessment between the 2 sample populations, which can be explained by the similar perception of living with the stigma of having an aged neck. There was noteworthy difference in the TTO and SG utility score assessments between the 2 sample groups. Medical students were willing to sacrifice 1.05 years of life less than the sample from the general population and accept 4% less chance of mortality for a neck rejuvenation procedure if subjected to stigma. This finding may be explained by the assumption that medical personnel are generally aware of the increased risks associated with such surgery, including mortality, and thus are less willing to sacrifice chance of mortality and life-years for surgical procedures.

Regression analyses using age, race, and education as independent predictors showed that age was inversely proportional to the TTO and SG utility scores, decreasing a utility score of 0.002 and 0.004 for every increase in 1 year of age. Simply stated, one can conclude that older volunteers were more likely to sacrifice years of life and percent chance of mortality during a procedure for neck rejuvenation following massive weight loss.

Race, sex, income, and level of education were not independent predictors of the VAS, SG, or TTO utility scores for neck rejuvenation procedures. This finding is suggestive that different ethnic groups, different income levels, and sex do not perceive the stigma of treatment of the aging neck differently as they were not more willing to risk the chance of mortality from such procedures.

The utility scores for neck rejuvenation patients (VAS 0.89 ± 0.07; TTO, 0.94 ± 0.08; and SG, 0.95 ± 0.10) were higher than the respective utility scores for blindness. This finding suggests that those who participated in the study would be willing to take a theoretical chance of 5% mortality for a neck rejuvenation procedure to treat their aging neck and be willing to trade 2.1 years of their life based on risk/benefit perception.

Living with the stigma of an aging neck following massive weight loss can now be objectified using utility scores. These utility scores were comparable to utility scores of other health states associated with a relatively poor quality of life (eg, obstructive sleep apnea syndrome; TTO, 0.94; SG, 0.97).14 This study is limited by the fact that the sample populations included may not be representative of an entire society. Cost-effectiveness studies may also be limited by our sample bias. A major strength of our study, however, is the large study population (n = 102 participants). We have also managed to use subgroup analysis to illustrate those participating understood the study and rated utility scores of neck rejuvenation regardless of their level of education.

There are few objective research tools available to quantify the impact of potential facial rejuvenation procedures on a patient’s life, and few studies exist that quantify a preoperative assessment of various health states in facial appearance. The method used in this study has been described as a cost-effective alternative for measuring quality of life.18 For cost-effectiveness analysis, quality of life is expressed by a single index measure intended to convey the utility that a person derives from his or her health state. The ratio of increased costs divided by the quality-adjusted life years gained by a medical intervention represents the cost-effectiveness ratio.35 Decisions on allocation of financial resources for health care are increasingly guided by cost-effectiveness analyses. Because the utility index is a main component of such analyses, its reliable measurement is essential.14 The Panel on Cost-Effectiveness in Health and Medicine, the authoritative consensus group convened by the US Public Health Service, recommends using societal valuation (the preferences of the community or the general public) of quality of life in its “reference case” cost-effectiveness analysis, while noting that patients with a condition may rate quality of life with that condition higher than other community members.12,30,36

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In conclusion, the quality of life of living with an aging neck following massive weight loss requiring a neck rejuvenation procedure is comparable to living with obstructive sleep apnea syndrome.14 We have demonstrated this with a measure of utility scores for the aging neck (VAS, 0.89 ± 0.07; TTO, 0.94 ± 0.08; and SG, 0.95 ± 0.10) that can be used for comparison with other disease states and for the analysis of cost-effectiveness. Our sample population, if faced with an aging neck following massive weight loss, would be willing to potentially undertake a neck rejuvenation procedure with a theoretical 5% chance of mortality and would be willing to trade 2.1 years of existing life. Further psychological and ethical studies are recommended.

Slavin, editing manuscript; Samuel J. Lin, editing, writing manuscript.
